All Reviews

  1. Really well made, nice heavy duty product. It arrived yesterdayI tried it out last night, not sure why ppl would give it a negative review. Its pretty straightforward on how to use properly. Insert 1/8 inches into area you need to trim and turn the lower half back and fourth. I want to mention there was an issue w my order but The company upgraded my order and even sent me an additional one for free. This is a handy lil item to have, plus its small shape and design are nice too. Its just a little longer in size than a AA battery and about the same weight as well.
  2. I had one for 20 plus years and dropped it on the hard floor and this is a replacement for that unit. Their is no comparison between the two units. This one is a terrific upgrade at a reasonable price.
  3. Most excellent. I had been using scissors for decades, and had suffered from some nasty hair pulls. These do a great job without the pain.
  4. So far so good....Ask me again in a couple of months....
  5. better than I've ever had!
  6. No batteries - what a concept.
  7. Works great. Definitely is important to read the 1-2 sentence instructions: rotate the wheel back and forth, not continuously in one direction. If you run the wheel in one direction for several turns, it probably will pull on your hairs from time to time which is unpleasant. If you use it as suggested, it works better than the electric model I had that died.
  8. I just purchased this product because I was tired of trimming the old fashioned way. I have used this years ago from a friend and had a horrific experience, but now that I own it, it's the best product for this need. The reason for such a horrible experience was because I used it incorrectly. You have to twist the item to cut the hair, but the key is not to twist in one direction the entire time. If you read the directions it specifically states to twist back and forth, and now the product works without any pain. I highly recommend this product.
  9. All it does is tangle up in the hair and then you have to yank it out. I wouldn't spend $5 on this product.
  10. I read a couple reviews that said that the this thing would pull nose hairs from time to time. That has not been the case for me. It works great. I like that you don't need to charge it or use batteries. A trimmer should not be as complicated as all that.
  11. Hard to use, doesn't trim very well, left me with painful ingrown hairs. Look into a Wahl rechargeable nose hair trimmer, that's what I am using now and I am very pleased with it.
  12. This item uses old time values. No batteries or plug ins, just functional manual trimming. If you want a trimmer that works, this is the one for you.
  13. Gets the job done - but pulls like crazy. I like its precision - gets to hard to reach spots that my electric one won't - but hesitate to use it because it hurts!
  14. I had one before but lost it. Very well made, will last a lifetime. Far better than electronic versions which break all the time.
  15. popped it out of the plastic and right into my nose. span it a few times and my nose hair was gone. i could not even feel it cutting the hair. super sharp felt no tugging of hair. quick rinse in the sink and good to go. highly reccomend this product. Merica!

  18. I originally wrote a 1-star review here because the one I bought off amazon did nothing but pull hairs. I put it away and forgot about it. Because there were many satisfied customers leaving good reviews here, but my old one didn't cut hairs at all, just cinched and yanked them.<br /><br />I got an email response the same day. And two days later I have a replacement. And it works GREAT! Didn't even have to return the old one. I'm really really satisfied with the product, but even further, I am wholly satisfied with the company and their customer support. This is way awesome. Thanks Groom Mate!
  19. Put it up by the nose-nostrils, give it a fast spin with your fingers and watch it do the job. Works great, cheap, and takes up very little room in the bathroom cabinet. This little guy is all I will ever need to take care of this grooming issue, as long as I don't loose it (it is rather small) I will never need to worry about embarrassing nose hairs. It's not electric and I do not see how it could ever break if you only use it for the purpose intended. I would recommend this.
  20. I was a little concerned that this may not be a good product at first since the manufacturer has obviously padded the reviews of it on this website. But it actually is really good. In my experiance the electric ones last at most a year or two. Although I've only had this manual version for a couple months based on the high quality of manufacturing it seems like it will last decades. But this high quality craftmanship leads to one drawback, since the metal is so thick and heavy duty it doesn't cut hair quite as short as the cheap thin metal electric trimmers so those hairs growing at the very end of your nostrils will stick out just a little bit no matter how long you try to cut them with this. But I'd rather deal with that then buying a new one every year.
  21. i Did not receive this producer i have no the cause of all this delay, more than ten days still did not received it and I have had no response to my inquiry from the seller, so this is shameful and bad service and I can not judge the product because I did not get it yet ....to me i will not give him any star ..<br />also i will not deal with seller any more ...
  22. This trimmer works very well: cuts hair without pulling, no batteries or cords to hassle with and easy to clean. Comes in a little case.

  24. I originally saw a similar product in a small grooming store in Australia for over $100, which gave me an idea to search for a similar product for a fraction of the price, when I found this little guy. I believe it has all the quality that the expensive one has, but at a fraction of the price. There is very little a person could do to dull this. I use it quite frequently and after about five years now, it is still performing just as good as day one. Just needs a little cleaning now and again.
  25. Without any doubt excellent. Very occasionally may pull a hair but that is definitely acceptable since no need of batteries and lifelong warranty.
  26. I wasn't expecting much out of this thang when I bought it, but I was very pleasantly surprised with how well this item works. AND, it doesn't pull on the hairs or tickle the inside cavities like the different battery operated units that I've owned in the past. It just does it's job very quickly and efficiently.
  27. You can forget about all those other battery-operated nose-hair trimmers. This one leaves them in the dirt. Simple, elegant, well made, cleaner, greener and it works. All day, every day. The only logical choice.
  28. If we're just talking about travel use, this would be a five on the convenience chart simply because you don't need to pack a charger or replace a battery. But, for $20 you expect something great. The Groom Mate Platinum XL is not without it's short falls unfortunately. Let me first say I've been using this thing for about a year now and have tried every way known to optimize use. The main problem with it, which I feel deducts 2 stars alone is that it is messy. Though a few cut hairs will get caught in the middle, almost all of the hair clippings get scattered in your nose. This means you will either inhale them and swallow them down your throw, or they will stay in your nose and fall out at random times as you are breathing in and out. Trust me, this is NOT something that you want to happen before a date. If you use this before a big occasion, and want to prevent this, you will find yourself picking your nose to pull out the hairs. They will, of course, get stuck inside your finger nails. The other two stars deducted are because there is a large amount of pain from pulling if you even slightly move the trimmer while you are twisting the bottom. Yes it has a life time warranty, but that does not mean the blade always remains sharp unfortunately. I'm going to keep this in my travel bag, but I would not consider this a 4-5 star product like most are giving it.
  29. I've used a series of inexpensive battery operated trimmers, but they have not worked well. They're usually cheaply made, don't trim well, require batteries (kind of wasteful for such a simple task), and most annoyingly, tickle the inside of my nose to the point where I can't stand them. I stumbled on this while searching on Amazon for another battery-operated trimmer. Based on reviews, the one I was looking for apparently is not well liked...But a link was on the Amazon page to this one. So this one sounded interesting, and it's made in the USA, not China. Pros: Small, durable, easy to carry for traveling. Works well; it trimmed much more than my larger battery-operated ones. It needs no batteries, and is made in the USA. It doesn't pull hairs or tickle my nose (Finally!), and it makes no noise. Cons: It's smaller than you think after seeing the picture above. That's good for traveling, but it makes it slightly awkward to use. If it were a bit larger you would be able to get a better grip on it. So an elderly person with arthritis in their hands would probably have a hard time using it. Also, I wish it trimmed slightly closer than it does. My nose tickles easily and makes me sneeze a lot, so I was hoping to almost eliminate the hairs, but instead it leaves a mm or two. This is more of a personal annoyance, so it likely will not bother most people. Considering basic shipping is included, the price is reasonable, but more than most other trimmers. If it lasts a long time it will have been worth it.
  30. I purchased this as a gift for my brother which may seem strange but we're talking about a guy that pretty much has everything he needs and wants. He was recently complaining about the lack of a decent nose hair trimmer and figured that he would have to spend at least $100 in order to get one that worked. I did a little research and decided to surprise him with the Groom Mate Platinum XL. He put the product to use right away, claiming it to be painless and easy to use. He added that it is \\"the best gift I've received in a long time.\\" Now I know what I will be getting for my two other brothers. Maybe not the most exciting- but definitely useful, practical and a real surprise! You can't beat the price- free shipping! and stellar customer service. I highly recommend this product.

  32. This trimmer is unique because it does not operate on batteries. Instead, you twist the bottom back and forth to make it work. It effectively cuts the hair, but it takes much longer to achieve results than a battery-operated one would. It also rips the hair sometimes which is painful. It's not very precise, and you have to position it multiple times before it actually cuts in some places. It works overall, it's just not very efficient.

After the initial \\"tickle\\" it works great. Have had it now for 2 months and will never go back to a battery operated device. The size is perfect too. Travels like a dream.

  36.   40. I am completely satisfied with this product. I have used a motorized nose & ear hair trimmer before and tried using scissors. I find this device to be superior to both. I previously used some mainstream brand of electric ear/nose hair trimmer. I found that it annoyed me in many ways. First the thing heats up, which also makes the peculiar smell these things typically have(i guess from the lubricating oil) worse. Also it made a decent bit of noise. I was afraid that it was going to eat my face when I was using it. Using scissors was just a bad idea for me.. a few cuts later and I'm on Amazon looking for a replacement. The manual control of the device feels much more natural for me (better than sticking something electric making a loud WHIRRRRING noise inside my nose). The Groom Mate makes little to no noise. Very simple to clean. Feels very well constructed. The device is VERY compact so it is another huge benefit over the electric. Also, another implication of the fact that it is manually operated: NO BATTERIES! In terms of speed comparison I actually think that this product is faster than using the electric. I frequently found that I had to go over the same place over and over or spend a lot of time in one place in order for the electric trimmer to work well. However the Groom Mate seems to work more reliably which helps to get things done faster. I would highly recommend this product to anyone searching for a simple yet effective ear/nose hair trimmer. Especially those who don't relish the idea of putting a noisy, smelly, hot motorized blade inside their head. When I bought my Groom Mate it was being offered by BEI - PHR Systems, Ltd. I just want to say that the shipping from them was very fast. I was quite satisfied with my transaction.
  41. I have tried many power trimmers in the past. Several from Sharper Image, cheap ones, expensive ones, all kinds... As a man, I gravitate towards things that are 'powered' and make noise because that's what men correlate with efficacy... Not here, Jack. All of the power ones I've used suck. I'm always scrambling to find batteries, they die quickly, the blades aren't sharp enough, they pinch and grab...The list goes on and on... But this magical little device is simply amazing. Upon arrival, I tore open the packaging and used it right away. It's small, really small. About as long and wide as my index finger. It's heavy, and I can tell it is well made. I inserted the tip into my nostril, and like the instructions said, I twisted the bottom half back and forth; I couldn't even tell anything was happening, and after a little while, I removed it from my nose, and was amazed: totally and completely trimmed. No noise, no pinching, no batteries- rinsed the tip and I was done. What a wonderful device. The shipping from the seller was also very fast and I paid ~$19 for the device. Well worth the price considering a lot of the \\"nice\\" powered ones are $20+. Highly recommend this product and company.

  71. What a marvelous idea - non-battery operated nose-hair trimmer, had I known, I would have bought this years ago. This is the 3rd nose-hair trimmer I've purchased, the very first one was a battery operated one that got wet one day and the battery leaked into the device and corroded it. The second one I still have, but I've already replaced one corroded battery and I have to shake it or tap it on the counter to sometimes get the blades to start turning. So now comes the Groom Mate Platinum XL Nose hair trimmer - a finely built precision instrument, just twist quickly back and forth and it works great. The first time I used it, I was shocked by how much it cut and the included brush was pretty handy, I thought I had Grizzly Adams inside my nose. The only observations (but this is still a 5 star product) are that the trimmer itself is stainless and has a metallic smell to it and well..you're putting this up in your nose, so you can expect to really smell the metallic smell. Also, the included brush is extremely useful, as I don't like to get this trimmer wet (even though it is stainless steel), but I wish there was an integrated holder to hold the trimmer WITH the brush, as there is only a carrying case for the trimmer itself. Ever so often I have to dig into the drawer to find the little brush. My search for the ultimate nose hair trimmer is over and it is this non-battery stainless steel one!

  78. There's not much to say--it has one simple function and it does it well. Unless you meticulously clean it with a tiny pipe cleaner, they're stuck. Which might be a good reason to keep this hidden away or inside a container, since your wife or roommate might not appreciate looking at a gadget that has your nose-hairs stuck in the top of it. The other thing is that while this has a lifetime manufacturer's warranty...the manufacturer is in New Zealand! For the amount of money you'd pay to send it there for repair, you might as well buy another one! In any case, the construction is solid, and I imagine I would probably lose the thing in a move before it actually breaks.

  99. I have never purchased a nose hair trimmer before, so I have nothing to compare this to except bumbling around with my nail scissors trying to use them for this purpose. I am able to do a nice job on my nose hair quickly, painlessly and better than spending more time on the job with my little nail scissors. You just give the tip a rinse with alcohol or water after use. EASY! I wish I would have had one of these years ago! I expect this product to seriously last. I love how well-made it seems to be. I LOVE IT!

  103. I read the great reviews of this product and had to try it. I bought it back in July and was doing well the first few times I used it. Then for some reason, when I would twist it to use it, it would grab the nose hair, which was painful!! I tried it one more time at another day after cleaning it and making sure nothing was stuck inside. It hurt again! So on Sept 18, I went to the website and emailed customer service since they have a 100% money back guarantee. I stated my situation. I got an email back within an hour from John, the president of the company. He said, \\"I am really sorry to hear that you are experiencing a problem using your Groom Mate nose hair trimmer. Ocassionally, the rotary blade system will go out of alignment for any number of reasons including maybe banging up against a rigid surface and this will cause the trimmer to stop turning smoothly. We do offer an unconditional lifetime warranty with free product replacement on all of the trimmers that we manufacture. I would like to know if you would like to receive a brand new Platinum XL (with no charge shipping) as well as one of our new leather pouches with cleaning brushes. If so, simply reply to this email and include your current mailing address and we will get it right out to you.\\" I wanted a refund but since so many people were happy with it. I emailed him back with my mailing address. That was on a Friday. Today is Monday and I received the replacement! I was shocked by the speed! I have not tried out the replacement but I'm sure it'll be better. Just want to give 4 stars for the product cause the first few times I used it, it worked great. I want to give 5 stars for customer service!!!

  109. This is a manual (finger operated) nose and ear hair cutter. Slow but relatively effective - nicely machined. Twist the base and the cutters rotate slowly and any hairs that happen to fall within its cutters will be sheared. Only rarely, will you feel any pulling of hairs - the blades seem quite sharp.<br /><br />This device is quite slow compared to a battery operated device but after my Panasonic battery operated cutter failed after only a few uses, I decided a manual cutter was the better alternative.<br /><br />Given the quality of the machining - this little device may last a lifetime. It's made of stainless steel. Yes: It is slow, Yes: It may occasionally pull a hair or two but it works and it was designed and manufactured with considerable care. I should add that at times it can be quite difficult to position this device while still being able to twist the base. So it is hardly ideal but there is little doubt that it will work reliably.<br /><br />I'm not aware of any electric cutter that will last. Check out the reviews of electrical cutters here on Amazon - they often fail.<br /><br />I'd happily pay $50.00 or more for a quality electric cutter but they don't seem to exist. Given that fact - this little MANUAL cutter may be your best choice for personal grooming. I still look forward to a reliable electric cutter.<br /><br />UPDATE (March 2010): 4 months after I purchased this cutter I have once again purchased another electric cutter simply because I was so frustrated with this manual cutter. While this manual cutter works - it is quite slow and difficult to position while still being able to turn the knob at the end of the unit. Nevertheless I'll always have it as a back-up. Time will tell whether my new electric cutter will last beyond a few uses.<br /><br />UPDATE (April 2012) I have not used this cutter in a few years. While nicely machined it is too difficult to position while still being able to turn the knob at the back of the unit. I've gone back to a battery operated cutter.o a battery operated cutter.

  116. [[ASIN:B000EBFJXS Groom Mate Platinum XL Nose & Ear Hair Trimmer]]<br /><br />Trimming nose hair is not the most glamorous activity in the world but a necessary one. You get to the age where you must do it or you risk looking like one of the animals in the wild. I have tried battery operated nose hair trimmers that took longer than expected with frustrating results, even the with expensive ones. I usually had to resort to using regular nose hair trimmer scissors because the hair on the sides would not be trimmed. The Groom Mate Platinum XL is worth every penny. It works by rotating the latter half of the device and maneuvering the trimmer side to side. The blades are so sharp that at first I did not think it was working. Simply stated, the Platinum XL works fantastic. The best part is that I trim less often because the trimmer works so well. At first I was leery on using a non-battery operating trimmer but this is the best trimmer available at any price. Plus, the company is the type of company you want to support. They are personal in their feedback and really care about customer feedback. They are a good company where products are made in the great USA. I highly recommend this product.

I was very disappointed. I wrote an e-mail to John Bellm, the president of Bei-PHR Systems. I explained the situation in detail and he wrote back in about an hour or two and told me he was sending me a replacement unit at no cost because there is a no questions asked, unconditional lifetime guarantee. It came express mail 1 1/2 days later. I was blown away. The trimmer works, but you have to get used to it. I found I had to hold it in one place, turn the bottom, then move on to the next spot but not while I am turning. I suspect people who claim it pulled hairs, were moving it as they were turning it. I like to think I am a smart shopper and an educated person, I can fully appreciate this trimmer and how John stands behind his product.

  131. This isn't a glamorous item to own, but guys over the age of 25 or so definitely need to have one. I've tried a variety of the battery-powered devices over the years, and while they worked fine with some patience, they required a lot of in-and-out because the openings for hair are so small to keep from nicking your skin with the spinning blade. The openings here are larger, so all of your hair is easily in the way of the blade, and you're in complete control of the blade so you can stop if you feel anything pinching (I never have). It takes literally 5 seconds a week for me to do this, while it used to take 30 seconds or a few minutes to get those random long hair to get caught in the tiny slot of battery-powered trimmers. I never feel pulling with this, either, and I certainly felt that from time to time with other devices. This thing is built like a tank, I have no doubt it will last for years and years. I'm giving some as gifts now because they are so great and most guys don't know there is a better, cheaper option than the $20 electric trimmers sold at the drugstore.

Still, this thing is tiny, and would almost seem too small if not for the fact that small makes it extremely useful for travel carry. Highly recommended for that purpose!<br /><br />In terms of comfort, I find it much more so than the battery trimmers that just feel bizarre to use. If you turn it too fast, I can see how you could easily pull a hair rather than cut it, but the thing is plenty sharp, so just take your time with it and that will not be a problem. It doesn't take any more time to do that than to try and rush through the procedure and it is a lot less unpleasant.<br /><br />The product is very well made, much better than the battery trimmers at the same price point, that's for sure.   181. I'm very happy with this trimmer.   187. Had I read the copy more thoroughly, I probably would have bought the battery powered trimmer that I ended up purchasing from a local salon supply store.   188. I had a cheap electric nose hair trimmer that never worked particularly well. It was surprisingly difficult to get the hairs to wander inside the housing to where the spinning blades lived. So I found this little guy on amazon, and was skeptical. How could a hand-turned razor be better than an electric one? Wouldn't it tend to pull on the hairs from the slower speed? Still, the reviews were good, so I gave it a shot. I am now a believer. Nothing, neither my old electric trimmer nor the tiny pair of scissors I own, has ever done as good a job of taming the shrubbery growing out of my schnoz. On top of that, no need for batteries, it seems to clean easily, and the packaging boasts of a lifelong warranty. You twist the bottom half of the shank to spin the blades. It twists fairly easily, and you don't even have to twist it that quickly. I've had a single hair get pulled. I was lowering the trimmer from my nose, and the hair must have been at ju-u-st the right point to be half-cut and gripped by the blades. Since then, I make sure that I keep operating the blades as I take it away from my face and it's never happened again.

When it dropped, one of the outer circle blades was bent ever so slightly in toward the path of the inner blade unit. That was enough to jam the rotation of the inner blades that were not unable to get past the one bent in outer blade that was now blocking teh path of the smooth rotation. Is this a reason not to buy it? Not in the least. Even though it can painfully get hung up on a nose hair or two as you manually spin it [no need for batteries] to get the job done, it is absolitely 100% better than the cheap plastic jobs. It was a gift and when I went to replace it on line I was amazed that it was not at least $40! I ordered a replacement right away! Every guy over 21 needs some kind of tool for good hair grooming. This is the best I have had and was given to me by my young son who has one of his own.

  243. I think this nose trimmer is probably as effective and smooth as any, if not more so, just based on what other reviews have said. I too carefully considered the reviews on the various models before deciding on this one since most of the electric options hover around the 3 star mark at best.<br /><br />I tried it out as soon as I recieved the item. I followed the directions and it trims very well. Only when you hold it too close or up against the inside of your nose did I find it to pull. If you hold it centered or there about, it cuts nicely and very smoothly without pulling at all.<br /><br />It's a little ackward to hold and twist while you have it in your nose or ear; but it's very workable. It's just not electric...<br /><br />The only real drawback, aside from probably not being as quick as an electric trimmer, is that it is near impossible to trim the outside of your ear on the flatter surfaces. Obviously, this item is intended to be inserted into your nasal cavity or your outer ear canal. And for that, I think it works nearly perfect for the most part. There is still probably good reason to keep a beard trimmer on hand; but this does work very well for the inside of the ol' nose and ear.
  244. Practice first, and you will be more successful with this product.<br /><br />Hold top portion with thumb and fore finger of one hand, and the bottom portion with thumb and forefinger of other hand.<br /><br />Keep top hand still and rotate the bottom half rapidly to one direction and then the other.<br /><br />Now, place the device near the hair you want to cut, hold the top part still in relation to the twisting bottom part and move the tip around to get the hair.<br /><br />It cuts ear hair and nose hair that is stiff and of almost any length, it does not work so well on fluffy hair that is short.<br /><br />I love these things and have three just in case I get the urge there is always one nearby.<br /><br />Pulling nose hair can cause dangerous infections in your nose that can move to your brain.<br /><br />I have used two other battery operated ones and they are both junk.

I think its because it feels like more of a high end product. Don't get me wrong, the TrimIt Wing (one handed version) is extremely well made, but the Platinum XL feels even more so. You will also be amazed on how easy and natural it becomes to use your hands with the Platinum XL then with a battery operated device. Just get one!

  263. There must be something wrong with me; I simply could not get this device to work. I'm not a stupid man; I tried every possible twist and angle and rotation speed and pressure adjustment that I could think of - every combination - and I simply could not get it to work as well as every battery-powered nose hair trimmer I've ever owned.   264. I used the Panasonic ER411 for several years before the blades started hitting the top blade enclosure causing a loud clanky noise, so I had to find a new trimmer. I searched amazon.com for reviews of nose hair trimmers, and this product had by far the best and most reviews. I was suspicious that this was not a battery-powered trimmer like the Panasonic one that I loved (but that model was no longer made). But, since I live 55 miles (one way) from the nearest store that sells trimmers, bec. I didn't want to make a special trip JUST for a nose hair trimmer, bec. I REALLY needed to trim my nose hairs, and because this product had a lifetime guarantee, so if I didn't like it, I could send it back and get a full refund, and bec. with 491 reviews at the time of my purchase, with a breakdown as follows:<br /><br />491 Reviews<br />5 star: (331)<br />4 star: (61)<br />3 star: (29)<br />2 star: (31)<br />1 star: (39)<br /><br />I decided to buy the Groom Mate Platinum XL and try it out for myself. To its credit, it arrived within 3 days of my ordering. I was very excited to test it. The compact and durable/solid/sturdy design is impressive and ingenious.<br /><br />BUT, I didn't like the Platinum XL nose hair trimmer and am returning it.<br /><br />1. When I used it, I had painful tugs and yanks of my nose hair, something I didn't have when I used the battery-powered Panasonic ER411. Not all the hairs had painful tugs and yanks, but many more than the Panasonic. My guess is that the speed at which a battery-powered trimmer's blades spin and cut is MUCH FASTER than the speed at which a human using two hands can twist the Platinum XL. The slower speed makes the device tug and yank, causing pain. It's analogous to taking a Band-Aid off your skin: if you pull it off fast/quickly, the pain is over quickly; however, it you pull it off slowly, the pain is more severe. It was very rare for me to have any pain, tugs, or yanks with my Panasonic ER411. I do note that several commenters said their battery-operated trimmer tugged and yanked, but their XL did not. I envy their experience with the XL; it just isn't my experience. I'm wondering if the fact that I always used brand new, fully juiced (not old) batteries when I use my Panasonic trimmer helped me have pain-free and tug/yank-free trimming.<br /><br />2. The XL does NOT cut the very base of the hair's shaft; it leaves several millimeters of nose hair there, hair that my Panasonic trimmed, almost right down to the skin. When I trim my nose hair, I want it done right and completely. I don't want semi-long hair left in my nose, which makes me have to trim yet again in a week or 2. With my Panasonic, I was able to trim once every 4 weeks, about as often as I cut my head hair.<br /><br />3. It's slow and time-consuming. With the battery-powered trimmer, trimming my nose hairs took 3 minutes max, and I really pushed it deep into my nostrils to get the hairs hiding in the back. With the XL, it is SO SLOW. It takes forever to just do one nostril, and it does that with more painful tugs and yanks than the Panasonic did.<br /><br />4. You have to use 2 hands to operate the XL. With my Panasonic, I liked the freedom of one-handed use, so I could use my other hand/fingers to bend or lift my nose in a way to allow the trimmer to better reach and trim areas it couldn't without the bending/lifting.<br /><br />I'm not a complainer or a perfectionist, and I feel badly writing this review (especially since I'm so outnumbered by folks who wrote positive reviews), but it is the truth as I experienced it. I don't have an alternate/substitute trimmer yet, as again, it's a long drive to the store for me, but I'm gonna have to get a battery-powered one, possibly another Panasonic.<br /><br />2/20/10 update: Groom Mate has promptly and without hassle refunded my purchase.<br /><br />4/10/10 update: I have purchased and am VERY HAPPY with the WAHL Ear, Nose, and Brow Wet/Dry Battery Trimmer, Model 41559-300N that I purchased at Bed, Bath, and Beyond for $19.99. I have used it once, and although it took a little more time to cut the nose hairs than my trusty Panasonic ER411 did, it cut down to the base of the hair like I wanted/left just a tiny stub behind and did not painfully tug or yank any of my hairs. I have used it only once, but I am very happy with it and highly recommend it. The packaging indicates the product has a generous 30-day money back guarantee and a 3-year limited warranty.have used it once, and although it took a little more time to cut the nose hairs than my trusty Panasonic ER411 did, it cut down to the base of the hair like I wanted/left just a tiny stub behind and did not painfully tug or yank any of my hairs. I have used it only once, but I am very happy with it and highly recommend it. The packaging indicates the product has a generous 30-day money back guarantee and a 3-year limited warranty.
  265. Having read a bunch of other reviews, I thought that this product may be the \\"wet shave\\" of nose trims. Meaning that I was hoping it would be more comfortable, closer and a cleaner cut. Personally I didn't find it to be any better then my Panasonic electric trimmer. I couldn't get it to cut as close and it did take longer.   266. This is a well-engineered product. The design is excellent for nose hair trimming. Ear hair...not so much. This little trimmer is much better than the battery-powered ones I have used.
  267. Ok, after all the hype and controversy (see discussion board on this product) about fake 5-five star reviews being put up by either this company, its employees or a marketing firm, it seems that the product can stand on its own merits without the phony one-shot reviews.<br /><br />The device is solidly made from metal and is about the size of a short pencil but a little bit broader. The device works by inserting the cutting mechanism into your nostril or ear and then rotating the knurled barrel clockwise and counter clockwise. After the first use it was amazing how thorough a job it did with unsightly nose hair. Since the device is made entirely out of stainless steel, a quick rinse under the faucet and you're done.<br /><br />The reason why this device doesn't get a perfect five is based upon two things. Although the ad \\"guarantees\\" that the device will not pinch or pull, it does occasionally. But after some time with it, it is really due to user error more than anything else. The way to use this properly is to make sure your hand is absolutely still while you are using the device. If you are rotating the barrel while you are moving it or withdrawing it, you'll have a hair or two snag on the cutter. This can be entirely avoided if you are careful about using this trimmer on a section at a time. The instructions could have pointed this out to save you some infrequent painful experiences but it omits this.<br /><br />The second reason why this product doesn't get a perfect score is due to the fake and phony reviews about this product. The reviews are usually very short (and glowing) but if you click on the authors, you'll see that a good many of them are only one-shot reviews or are among a series of three or four hastily written reviews all occurring on the same day... apparently bogus reviews put up to inflate the ranking of this product. No seller should ever get a perfect rating when they attempt to boost their own amazon ranking by writing phony reviews. Although amazon customers have pointed out these bogus reviews regarding this device, the owner of the company merely replies by accusing the negative reviews of his product as being false...he never denies the fact that many of the five-star reviews are indeed fabricated.<br /><br />But if you overlook the bogus review issue and take your time when you use this product, you'll know that it is a good one for the purpose it serves.h amazon customers have pointed out these bogus reviews regarding this device, the owner of the company merely replies by accusing the negative reviews of his product as being false...he never denies the fact that many of the five-star reviews are indeed fabricated.<br /><br />But if you overlook the bogus review issue and take your time when you use this product, you'll know that it is a good one for the purpose it serves.

  272. Been using this for years. Great quality product.
  273. Its been saving me the pain of trimming my nose hairs by scissors,<br /><br />Some people say that it pulls on the hairs, causing pain. I've found out what makes it pull:<br />Keep the bottom part spinning at all times, most incidences of pulling are caused when it clamps down on, but doesnt fully cut the hair, and the user stops spinning the blade. The weight of the trimmer then pulls down, causing pain, if you keep it spinning at all when entering and exiting your nostril, it wont pull.<br /><br />Also, STORE it in the plastic tube it comes with! I tossed mine a few months after I got it. A business trip later, and a trip in my luggage, and one of the tips bent. This causes unsmooth turning, and can also result in pulling hairs. I bought another one and keep it in the plastic container now, no damage, no hair pulling
  274. Built to last, but I'm sorry to say that if fails to do the job well in my nostrils. It will last you a lifetime, no doubt about that. The problems is, it really does not work as you might think it will. First, its very difficult to manauver it. It is quite awkward since you have to use both hands and make the just the right amount of twists and turns just to get to the hair. When you finally manage to cut hair, you will notice that it simply doesnt cut it close enough. That is a big problem for me because I had better results with my Panasonic nose hair trimmer that was much easier to use too. The whole point of a hair trimmer is to cut hair to where its not noticable! Im sure other electric trimmers will give you better results as well. Also, you need a screw driver just to open it up to clean it! It has grease on the blades, so all the hairs get stuck to it. You have to wipe off the grease and apply more (if you have any). Please, dont buy into the hype of if being \\"Made in USA\\". Those words simply dont mean anything anymore. Do yourself a favor and buy any of the Panasonic ones.

The trick to it not pulling a hair is to only move it in or out or around while slowly turning the cutter so it cuts and does not pull. If you do not have the ability to not shake then pass up on this and get the battery models with constant turning blades. This one is simple and effective on nose hair, I have no need or desire to try it anywhere else. Works perfectly and easily, just move it only while turning the cutter.

  340. DO NOT underestimate the need to trim your nose hair gentlemen (or sometimes ladies). It ranks up there with dirty underwear in terms of hygenic no no. Yes, it is a dirty job, but you must do it you want to look civilized. If you can pick your nose, you can trim your nosehair.<br /><br />I have used the Panasonic ER112 (electric trimmer), the small scissors that comes with the Swiss Army knife, and Groom Mate Platinum XL to trim my nose hair.<br /><br />All 3 products I have used did their job well. But this Groom Mate Ultra Super Duper Deluxe Platinum-Gold XL is the best.<br /><br />The Panasonic ER112's blades wore out after about a year and it completely stopped working after two years (its motor died). The Swiss Army scissors worked beautifully as well but its effectiveness was largely dependent on my skill. This product shaved my nosehair as close, if not closer, than the Pansonic's electric trimmer with hardly any effort or skill on my part.<br /><br />The steel cutting mechanism do not wear out but it must be turned manually by hand. This device is also fairly small, about the size of an average sized pinky. Some say this product takes longer than the electric trimmers. True, but barely. I would say the electric trimmers takes about 1.5 minutes and this product takes about 3 minutes. Trust me, those extra 1.5 minutes are definitely worth it. It is similar to the difference you feel between an electric shave and a blade shave.<br /><br />Some say this trimmer hurts your nose. That would be true only if you are taking psychodelic drugs and imagine that your nosehairs are like your fingers. Please beware, if you can feel the bacteria on your nose, you might be able to feel the pain in your nose while this trimmer is massacring your nosehair by cutting them into pieces.<br /><br />This Groom Mate Platinum XL is completely made of steel and does not feel flimsy like most electric trimmers. It is definitely designed to last and be effective over your lifetime.

  347. I have tried several hair trimmers over the years--small scissors, other manual trimmers, and all manner of electric trimmers. This is my favorite because of how easy it is to use and how compact it is. I used my last one for about 3 years before I dropped it in the sink, causing a small misalignment in the blades. I just purchased a second one and with the proper care, it should last me a lifetime.<br /><br />Tips:<br />-The included brush is handy, but once in a while, clean it with a blast of compressed air and lube it with some food grade mineral oil to keep its operation smooth. Dont just use any grease or oil because you are sticking this thing up your nose!<br />-Always keep it in its case when you aren't using it.<br />-Use the proper technique: After inserting it into your nose, don't just turn it continuously in one direction--you are suppose to turn it back and forth.<br /><br />Pros:<br />-Solid, simple construction. No motor to fail. Beefy blades that will probably never need sharpening.<br />-No batteries to replace or charge.<br />-Doesn't pull hair or tickle my nose.<br />-Compact<br />-Made in the USA<br />-Lifetime warranty<br />-Stainless<br /><br />Cons:<br />-Dont let the heft and robust appearance fool you, the cutting head does not take any abuse. Any misalignment in the blades caused by a bump or drop and this thing will be pulling hair instead of cutting it.<br />-The case, which is very necessary due to the first con I listed, seems like an afterthought. Its just a cheap plastic piece of tubing with a cap. Seems flimsy and does not provide much protection. I am still looking for a better case.<br />-------------------------<br />8 YEAR Update: Back for my third one today. These are small and slippery little buggers. One small drop into the sink or onto the floor and the blades will become irrecoverably misaligned turning this into a medieval torture device. My second replacement didn't operate as smoothly and required extra care not to pull hairs. Still, you cant beat the simplicity of this device. No batteries to worry about. You can revoke my man card if you want, but I must also add that it doesn't tickle my nose as much as electric trimmers.are not to pull hairs. Still, you cant beat the simplicity of this device. I really like the fact that it is stainless and will not rust anytime in the future. I don't know how everyone else uses these but I start twisting the device before I even put it in my nostril. As I ease it up in the nostril while twisting and turning, I feel absolutely nothing. At first, I wondered if it was even doing anything! A quick visual inspection of the nostril showed all of the lower hairs were cut very short! So for the first time in longer than I can remember, I can breathe out of my nose and I don't have a tickling sensation. What a relief! The only downside I have noticed is for the remainder of the day that you trim your nose hairs, the hairs feel sharp/prickly if I pinch my nostrils together. After about 24 hours, I can pinch my nostrils all I want and I don't feel that prickly sensation. I would imagine any type of nose hair trimmers would cause this effect on me, so this is not a con for this product. In conclusion, I am very very pleased with this product and hope it lasts a very long time. Thanks to all of the Amazon.com reviewers out there that help everyone make smarter and better informed decisions on the products here.

  386. I shouldn't have waited so long to buy this. I've been through several electric nose hair trimmers, including a Phillips beard trimmer with a nose trimming attachment (what a waste that thing was), and all of them were more of a spinning pair of tweezers that simply pulled out the hairs.<br /><br />I suppose my nose hairs are a bit more husky than most peoples'. It runs in the family. Anyway, I've been looking at this thing for a while thinking what a novel idea it was, but that it might not work too far beyond the novelty.<br /><br />Box opening revealed a tiny little thing that made me wonder how much dexterity it would require to use this it on my nose and ears. The answer is not much. You just move it around in small, slow circles while slowly twisting the bottom half back and forth. It was so painless I didn't really think it did anything, but in reality, it was easily twice as fast (also totally painless) as any other trimmer I've tried.<br /><br />No batteries. No cord. A tiny little plastic sleeve about three inches (more like two and a half--I didn't measure it) and about 5/8ths of an inch in diameter is all the space it takes up in my shaving kit for travel. Using around my ears was just as easy.<br /><br />Honestly--the Groom Mate (Platinum XL if that makes a difference) is totally painless and (as long as you have two hands) is mindlessly simple to use. If you can't use it, there's something wrong with you. If it's hurting you, you're using it wrong. Slow down (both nostrils and ears took less than two minutes to trim) and use your brain in addition to your hands and you won't have any problems. You'll thank yourself, and wonder why you didn't do it sooner, as I did.<br /><br />Also--the little screw allows you to take it apart for thorough cleaning (not really needed; you can rinse it) and oil it if it seems like it isn't turning easily enough. The scissors don't look as if they will ever dull by the way it was constructed. If it will trim my nostril forest, it will trim anything.<br /><br />I would say it would be the last trimmer I'll ever buy, but I will probably order a few more to stash one permanently in my travel kit, and a spare in case one rolls off the counter into the heating duct. If you're organized that won't be an issue for you, but I'm not.<br /><br />Update: 1/26/14:<br />I now understand the negative reviews. My trimmer rolled off of the counter and onto the floor. After that, it never worked right and I had to replace it. It is surprisingly fragile; if it pulls hairs out when you get it, it was likely mistreated during handling and should be replaced. It worked beautifully until I dropped it.

Worked wonders, even for running I can breath in more air, well it seems like it anyways. Could be I am just shocked at how naked m nose feels now. Highly recommended easy to use, does;t catch my nose hairs!!
  407. I bought this because I liked the idea of having a trimmer that doesn't require electricity. It cut the hair however it frequently pulls the hair.

  410. Owned one of these for over a year now, works as advertised and is easy to clean and doesn't show any signs of corrosion. In regards to some of the other reviews that claim that these &#34;pull hair&#34; it may be due more to errant arm or hand movements while rotating the cutter. I found that by supporting the cutter by resting my hand against my face while twisting the cutter knob with my other hand to provide the best pain free experience.<br /><br />Or you could just man up and yank those suckers out a pinch at a time and grin through the pain.
  411. Pulls hair pretty good.
  412. Yes the product is awkward to hold and operate at first but you can get use to that. My problem is it does not get close enough to the skin. I do not want any visible hair in my nose, and this product does not cut close enough to the skin to avoid this. Furthermore, they claim that the product does not pull hair, but it does. I have not used it one full time without it pulling some of the hairs.
  413. ABOUT MY OLD TRIMMER I used to use a rather inexpensive battery operated nose/ear hair trimmer. It was really underpowered -- the rotary blade would get stuck easily, and I was lucky just to get the blessed thing to turn on. Plus, I did not like having to deal with YABOD -- Yet Another Battery Operated Device. If it runs on batteries, they either have to be charged or replaced, and that's a nuisance -- the more YABODs you have, the bigger a nuisance it is. I've gone through a lot of cheap electric trimmers in my time (mostly for beards), and they just don't last. ABOUT MY NEW TRIMMER I was attracted to Groom Mate's Platinum XL because it is battery-free (not YABOD!) and manually powered (thus never underpowered). The quality of this item is superb -- it looks and feels absolutely indestructible. It comes with a lifetime warranty, and it's easy to see why: This thing will never break or wear out. TAKES SOME GETTING USED TO If you're accustomed to a battery-operated trimmer, working a two-handed manual trimmer does take a little getting used to. I have to admit that the first time I tried it, I thought it didn't work. I realized that it DID work when I saw all the little hairs in the sink after I rinsed it out, and (forgive me if this seems gross) all the little hairs in a tissue after I blew my nose. (I always blow my nose after trimming so that I don't inhale loose hairs.) TRY IT, YOU'LL LIKE IT Once I realized that the Platinum XL does in fact work, I really went to town on the ol' nostrils. It used to be an unruly jungle up there. Now, my nostrils are a thing of beauty! :-) Actually, two things of beauty, if you want to get technical about it. Best of all, after using this product, I literally breathe easier! Thanks to an unimpeded flow of air, my brain is getting more oxygen. Now my brain can run faster, jump higher, and solve difficult math problems without even breaking a sweat. Yes, this one product is going change my whole life. Well, not really -- but at least I'll look well-groomed while I'm living it. Plus, I've reduced my YABOD count by one. Sometimes, less really is more!

Okay, we both liked the fact that this little trimmer was:<br />constructed of sturdy metal;<br />didn't depend on batteries to operate;<br />and was made in the good old USA<br />...however, we are both too scared to use it.<br />The operating process is basically a simple one; just slowly and gently move your trimmer around your nasal passage with one hand, while twisting and turning the other end of the trimmer (which runs the blade) with your other hand. Simple, right?<br />The problem is that it can be a little tough to hold the business end of the trimmer steady while cranking the other end. Sadly after a couple of experiences of it grabbing a nose hair and ripping it out by the roots (user error, surely...brings tears to my eyes just at the memory) we have gone back to the old battery operated chinese trimmer.<br />*sigh*<br />If you are more steady of hand, please support this company and buy one!

  491. When I first opened up the trimmer I didn't bother to even read the instruction(how hard could a manual powered nose hair trimmer be). Well....painful was my answer.<br /><br />However, after reading the instructions it says use a back and forth(counter and counter-clockwise) motion of the blades. Don't just turn the knob in one direction or it will yank your hairs out.<br /><br />After, using it the proper way I haven't had one hair get pulled out and I'm very happy with my purchase.
  492. I was excited at the prospect of a well-built, stainless trimmer that would not require batteries. What I got was a mediocre, incompletely trimming, often-times hair pulling apparatus. Bummer.

  494. I bought this well-engineered piece of stainless steel in Oct. 2009; it is the best trimmer I've ever encountered. It's intuitive to use, doesn't require batteries, is easily portable, easy to clean, and most importantly, DOESN'T PULL HAIRS!<br /><br />I never had a single problem with it, until about a week ago--I'd recently moved, and the moving help I had apparently wasn't the most careful. I went to use it, and it wouldn't turn freely anymore. I'm assuming it must have fallen out of the box and landed on the cutting end. I emailed the company with my Amazon invoice, and they immediately shipped a new one to me, no questions asked! They even told me to keep the old one, in case I needed a spare set screw for the new one. It arrived today, and the quality and ease of use is identical.<br /><br />A great product, and responsive, responsible, and friendly customer service that stands by their product even 3 years later. They've got a loyal customer and an evangelist for life.<br /><br />Update: June 2016<br />Now, over 6 years later, this thing is still working perfectly. I rinse it out under hot tap water every time I use it, and blow out the extra water before putting it back in the cabinet. I have NEVER had it pull a hair *unless* I moved the trimmer without twisting. In other words, if it's in my nose, I'm twisting it until after it out of my nose. Again, I have never had it pull a hair otherwise. Just don't stop turning it while you move it around, and you'll be fine.
  495. If you need to eliminate all traces of nose hairs from your nose, then this is not for you.<br /><br />But if you are just an average Joe like me that just wants to keep nose hairs in check without using tweezers then this is for you.<br /><br />Just make sure and rotate the blades back and forth, not all the way around 360 degrees.<br /><br />I never used this for ear hair, that would require more coordination/reach that I have.<br />(EDIT) I have had this long enough to grow old enough for ear hair to be a problem, and yes even a uncordinated person like me can use this to get rid of extra long ear hairs.<br /><br />No batteries, small, solid construction, low price, seems to stay sharp after 5 years, easy to disassemble (only one screw) and clean if needed.<br />(EDIT) Its been a while longer and I still use the same unit. Blades are still getting the job done and I have never even thought of getting a new or different trimmer.<br /><br />Bottom line, this unit gets the job done good enough for me as an average guy.<br />But if you need those nose hairs cut so short you could be on the cover of a magazine, then get something else.
  496. This mechanical twister easily gets rid of those annoying nose hairs, doesn't use a battery, and actually is a lot more sturdy and solid than I expected. Good on you, Mate!
  497. initially, it didn't pull. after a few months of use, it pulls and snags nostril hairs. can be quite... uh... invigorating in the morning.

  503. This thing is amazing. Works much better than any electric model I have tried. Yes it has pulled a hair or two and it hurts like hell when it does..... It is more than worth it. When I first tried it, I didn't even realize it had worked. I looked in the top of the trimmer trying it for the first time and it was full of hair. I was amazed. This thing is well built and will never use an electric again.<br /><br />Update: I have been using this a few months now. I have figured out how to avoid the hair pulling. It is all about technique. Make sure you keep spinning the trimmer when you remove it from your nose and you won't yank any hairs. If you stop spinning and then remove it, sometime hairs get caught in the cutters mid clip and it will yank them out if you remove it while it is not spinning.
  504. cumbersome and painful to use. it sort of works but not nearly as good or painless as a pair of small scissors
  505. Has no signs of ageing, does what you'd expect. Be careful to not pull or twist both pieces or it will pull. Ouch. :)

  507. This product works very well, but read the instructions. Twisting back and forth definitely works better (i.e. less painful) than twisting in the same direction.

  516. I recently purchased this product in mid-December 2008. I read all of the reviews and had some concerns about the cutting length of this trimmer or if I'd have trouble operating a trimmer manually with two hands. I too have owned a few battery operated trimmers that have either broken down after a while or developed dull blades, which led to painful pulling of nose hairs. This trimmer is an absolute dream. For me, I am able to get it to cut down to at least 1/8\\", which is more than close enough for nose hair. I found it very easy to use. It does take getting used to using two hands to operate the trimmer, but I was able to adjust to it right away. As mentioned in the other reviews, I don't think it is even possible to cut yourself with the trimmer. The small size makes it very maneuverable so that you can get difficult to reach hair without having to worry about accidentally cutting yourself. Great trimmer - I highly recommend it.

This product has a great tactile feel to it and it should last a lifetime. This product is made in the USA and isn't it great to purchase something that's not made in China now. I think that this product is a great example of good American craftsmanship, not of the usual, use a few times and throw away type, that we have had to become so used of. I would recommend it as far superior to most others I have seen on the market, which are mainly electrical and made in some Asian country, where price was the overriding factor and not quality. Finally, I think the producers of the Groom Mate Platinum XL Nose & Ear Hair Trimmer, are of the old school in that they offer friendly and efficient service together with a great quality product.   615. This is a wonderful grooming tool, works great on the nose hairs. Easy to use, compact size, no need for batteries. Built well I'm sure it will last a long time. Does not pull the hairs, cuts smoothly.
  616. The Groom Mate Platinum XL is a fantastic nose hair trimmer. Due to its simple mechanical design, solid metal build and lack of electronics, the device should last 20-30 years. It's unlikely the blades will dull unless your nose hairs are tungsten filaments. I used it for over a week and found its operation intuitive and comfortable. Prior to the Platinum XL, I was using scissors with rounded tips. The Platinum XL is much better. Two minor thoughts for improvement: 1. Due to its cylindrical body, the Platinum XL rolls around. Please add a bevel to its sides to prevent rolling. 2. Not sure if you can bring this through carry-on in an airport. It looks like a small metal weapon.
  617. This product is a true God send. For years if I had nose hairs I either did the the quick yank & endure [The pain] or used a pair of nail clippers [Something picked up in Marine Bootcamp...lol]. Over the years I've tried many sub-standard electrical devices that proposed to solve the problem. The majority didn't cut worth a damn and if they did cut well it meant certain injury to sensitve parts of my face. I received the Groom Mate for my birthday and was thrilled. The beauty of the product is that it is manually operated with no plugins or chargers to deal with. The twisting motion needed to operate the device along with the blade design virtually ensures a safe, painless snip of those pesky overgrown nose hairs. It's made of stainless steel and compact so I can travel anywhere with it. I'm so impressed with the product I started giving it out as a small gift (Christmas, Birthday,etc...) to all my male friends and relatives.
  618. Seems to be made from excellent steel, but not the easiest thing to use. Will probably last forever, but using two hands to operate it makes it kind of cumbersome.
  619. This is one of the most solidly built products I've purchased in years. It feels like it is carved out of a solid piece of steel and it appears it will last several lifetimes. However, I find it slightly awkward to use compared to a battery operated trimmer and it will pull a hair if you do not hold the upper half still during use.
  620. I haven't used this long enough to comment on the product, but I have to give them credit for customer service. My groom mate worked at first. Maybe I used it twice. Then one day when I tried to use it, it was locked up. Nothing moved. I e-mailed the company on Jan 17, got a response on Jan 18, and today Jan 26 I got a new one in the mail. I was sure they were going to make me mail back the defective product and I wasn't looking forward to packaging it up, going to the post office, paying postage, waiting. I was also sure they were going to balk at mailing it to Canada. But no, they just mailed me a new one, no questions asked.
  621. The product is as good as the reviews suggest. No battery to worry about. Sturdy construction. Easy to use. Highly recommended for nasal hair.
  622. After lots of review skimming I decided to order this when I was also getting into wet shaving, as I had never been satisfied with any cheap electric trimmer I had used, and scissors/tweezers are not the safest/most painless way to go. I'm very glad I did. It is such a simple, well-built unit and I have no doubt it will last forever, which makes it an outstanding value. I personally don't mind paying a little more for quality, as it tends to last in the long run. The company has a lifetime return/satisfaction policy, which is rare these days. Basically, if you're a guy, and care anything about your appearance, you will at some point want to keep those pesky nose hairs in check (I hope??), and this is the perfect way to do it. Hold it with one hand and twist back and forth with the fingers of your other, while going around the inside of your nose. That simple. I experienced absolutely no pulling or snagging whatsoever. Great piece of kit, would recommend to anyone not happy with their current grooming item(s)!
  623. How simple can it be? Stick it up your nose and twist the base. It actually works. What have I been missing all of these years? All of these expensive AA battery powered electric nose hair trimmers substituted speed for a decent blade. The blade here is thick and it just slices all of the hairs without pulilng. All electric ones spin cheap thin blades really fast. They end up grabbing and yanking half the hairs. I cannot believe how well this little battery-less wonder works. I love the feel (solid little plug of metal), and it just works. What else can you say?

  671. It's surprisingly heavy (solid metal, I think).<br /><br />I've only used it once, but it cuts very cleanly without tugging (I read in the instructions to twist the bottom half back and forth quickly to avoid tugging/pulling). When pressed against my thumb, the tip doesn't pinch.<br /><br />I'm still getting used to using 2 hands to operate this, but it's not as difficult as I thought.<br /><br />For anyone who has used a safety razor, this feels like the trimmer equivalent of a well designed safety razor compared with a plastic cartridge. However, this one came with no case at all. I am sure those cases added to the cost, but I feel like a case of some kind is really important for a device like this.
  738. Not sure what people were complaining about with the hair pulling. They must have jungles in their noses. This little device is a great way to manage that nose and ear hair, it's painless (mostly), and doesn't use batteries or electricity! Off the grid nose hair management at it's finest!
  739. Pulls the hair out some times, but that just means it is the closest shave ever! The no batteries ever part makes up for it. Sweet!
  740. I love this thing. Just what the doctor ordered. This marvelous little doo-dad, no bigger than a pencil stub, absolutely works wonders! When I couldn't keep ahead of my nose and ear hair proliferation, and trimming with the round-tip scissors sometimes caused painful ingrown nose hairs, I realized that an instrument especially designed to cut the hairs well enough above the skin line to avoid the ingrown hair problem (which is very annoying, and also very painful) was definitely in order. Except when I looked in the medicine cabinet, there sat my battery-driven nose-hair trimmer, encrusted with a beautiful blue-green patina of battery corrosion. So I threw it in the trash, and immediately ordered this. I really looked forward to using this, because it was touted as not needing batteries of any kind, and was strictly mechanical. My experience with a cordless shaver caused me to order new cutting blades, when the real problem was just weak batteries. I had become convinced that the stubble on my neck and under my chin was too tough for a mere cordless shaver, when it finally dawned on me that the batteries just weren't getting the job done. But you don't realize it with a battery-powered shaver, because they are being perpetually recharged. You think the blades are dull, but the motor is actually just not turning fast enough. This is your first clue that the batteries won't last forever. But it doesn't become immediately apparent that this is the problem: You end up having to buy new blades before you figure it out. So I ordered a new corded electric shaver, and zipped right through my daily shave in virtually no time at all, and got a perfectly smooth, close shave, almost in an instant. Suddenly, the stubborn hairs on my neck and under my jaw were no longer any problem whatsoever. And, by the way: The new electric shaver cost less than batteries alone would have cost for the cordless shaver. On top of which, on that particular shaver, the batteries weren't simply plug-in replacement batteries; you actually had to have new batteries soldered in place - which meant that you had to find a dealer that would/could do it, and pay his price, whatever that might be. I hate batteries, anyway. They're a curse, and a source of endless frustration - not to mention being increasingly more expensive. Of course, we don't really have much choice, do we? If you've got a tool that uses batteries, no matter how much they cost, what are you going to do, not buy more batteries? I've gone through batteries on hedge trimmers, edgers, drills, lawnmowers, shavers, self-propelled golf carts, and now nose-hair trimmers, and I'm THROUGH WITH BATTERIES! Guess what? You can have a whole platoon of battery-powered tools, but without batteries, THEY ARE WORTHLESS! And there is no such thing as a universal battery, which will fit everything you've got that needs batteries. They are all different voltage, and all designed to fit only the specific tool they were made for, but not anything else. Every tool has it's own battery, designed to fit that particular tool. And of course, they all need the one, specifically designed battery for that particular application, and usually available only from the manufacturer of that particular product. Which means that whatever price they decide to charge you is the price you pay. But you do have an alternative. Your alternative is to do without. Or, very often, they discontinue that model, which means that you may or may not be able to get batteries for it. Of course, they usually come up with a &#34;new and improved&#34; model, which uses completely different batteries. And by a strange coincidence, the new model is always more expensive. The question arises: If you can no longer get batteries to fit your old tool - no matter if the tool is still in excellent condition, what good is it? Oddly enough, you may still be able to find batteries for it, but you discover that they cost more than you originally paid for the tool! Being faced with this situation a few times, I have decided to exercise my alternative: NO MORE BATTERIES! But with this little jewel, you won't ever need any kind of battery, and you'll get quick and easy nose and ear grooming, which leaves you feeling clean and neat, and with virtually no effort. How great is that? PS: From some of the reviews I've read, I suspect that one problem may be that people are twisting the handle, rather than just turning or twirling it back and forth, as recommended in the instructions. Just holding the top part steady, and twisting the bottom part back and forth with the other hand, does the job beautifully. About a quarter-turn to the right and back to the left is all it takes. I was a little concerned with possibly having hairs pulled or yanked from my nose - which is so painful it brings tears to your eyes. But not to worry: It's even easier to work the handle back and forth than it is to twist it, and that works to perfection. I have gotten fantastic results - right from the get-go, and I do love it.

I had hoped that the device would just rinse clean with a decently high pressure faucet, but I find hair will stay in the cutter blades, due to the tight clearances needed to do the cutting. You end up having to take the item apart to clean it - which of course is easy, but needing a screw driver in my bathroom already loses a star in my mind.   848. The trimmer seems to pull almost as many hairs as it cuts. You will have to insert the trimmer multiple times (3-4 per nostril) to catch all the hairs within the trimmer channels.
  849. This is a well made grooming tool. I don't think it will trim the hair as close as some of the electric trimmers but it is nice not to have to rely on batteries!
  850. I was looking for a small portable trimmer for travel and this is perfect. It can fit into a pocket and still does its job well. It might not be as fast as an electric unit, but works just as well

  852. I know this is a fairly well reviewed item. First off, the people who complain about pain should know that if you want the hair completely ripped out, you're going to have pain, just like getting your eyebrows plucked, something make-up artists have done to me before TV shoots. It's a little painful.<br /><br />I think this is okay for people who don't mind a tiny stem of the hair sticking out from where it was detached. However, for me this trimmer doesn't work as well as just ripping the hairs out manually. It's good to have around if you're running out the door and spot something that's really overgrown and needs to be taken out, but I didn't get a super-close result with it. It's the type of thing that others may have a much different result with, depending on how you're hair grows.
  853. I guess this is okay if you don't want battery issues but I found it difficult to use and annoying
  854. As detailed by many others, this unit is impressively constructed and I can well imagine it lasting forever, but the bottom line, for me, was how well does it groom the inner sanctum of my nose?<br /><br />Alas, not well enough. It's true I have very hirsute nostrils and it's true this gets a lot of those hairs, but it leaves too many to make it a winner.<br /><br />I get a lot more bang for my buck with those imported battery-operated trimmers, even if they have the half life of a fruit fly.<br /><br />Perhaps those with less hair and/or light colored hair (mine's black as coal) will find satisfaction, but I was excited to buy this after all the many rave reviews, but when it comes to trimming my nose hairs, you need to go big or go home, and this trimmer has found a new home in my wife's bathroom.<br /><br />Appreciate the effort, but it simply doesn't do enough. Not only does it fail to cut finer hairs, but no matter what you do, you cannot cut the hair close enough to the skin, leaving lots of unsightly nubs inside your nose.<br /><br />You can buy the aforementioned battery-operated trimmers on that famous auction site, where you can pay $2-$3 each if you don't mind the wait for shipping from China.<br /><br />Best of luck with your nose and ear hair issues, people.

  858. I've been using this for a bit over a year now to occasionally trim moderate nose hair, and I'm satisfied. I use it only in the nose, as I don't have protruding ear hair. The construction is solid, it functions well, and is easy to clean.<br /><br />Operation is simple: put it in your nose, gently move it around while twisting the bottom half. It trims the bulk well, but is rather difficult to target single hairs. There's been a few times where I had one stray hair that took a while to get. I've only had it pull hairs a few times out of the many times I've used it. I've never been cut or pinched by the mechanism.<br /><br />I clean it by rinsing with rubbing alcohol, then twisting the head under running water. The cut hairs come out easily, and it's ready for use again.<br /><br />Overall I'm highly satisfied with this product. The price is good, it works well and is easy to use, it doesn't use electricity, and is easy to pack for travel.
  859. To get to the point: As with everything I buy, I wanted a quality trimmer that would last. Somehow I missed the fact that this is a manually spun trimmer. Even so, I've had it now for a few years and wish to share the following:<br /><br />1. It is very well built.<br />2. It will \\"bite\\" you unless you follow the technique I describe below.<br />3. It will indeed last a lifetime.<br />4. I wish it WERE electric<br /><br />Save yourself from pain with this key point. Once you insert the device, do NOT move it around unless you are already spinning the blades. AND, when you stop spinning the blades, you had better be holding still. Vary from this approach and you will become fully aware of your humanity.<br /><br />Cheers!<br />Roger

Turned out that Romania is a fully modern country and I could have brought my Panasonic. I purchased one of these nose hair trimmers at WalMart and was pretty dubious. I grow copious nose hair and have been using this quality tool for five years. It does not pull my hair as much as the Panasonic, is still sharp after five years, and is no longer available in the local WalMart. I was tickled pink to find that it still existed on Amazon and am buying a second one for use in my office. This is a solid and quality product, made in the USA, and well worth the 30 bucks. I tried very carefully to unbend the outer finger but was not able to get it back in the exact correct position.   901. With so many glowing reviews on Amazon and other sites, I had to try this hair trimmer. At first, it lived up to the hype -- simple to use, smooth, no batteries needed.<br /><br />After a few months, though, the inside piece started to catch on the outside piece. It got to the point where I could barely turn it. i thought that maybe I had treated it poorly (dropped it or maybe I wasn't supposed to wash it with water), so I gave them the benefit of the doubt and ordered another one.<br /><br />This time, it only took a month for the same problem to happen.<br /><br />So I emailed the company about two defective hair trimmers. Their response: \\"We manufacture the Platinum XL trimmer to a very tight tolerance in terms of the inner rotary blade and outer shaft and if there is just a slight variance this could cause the skip or binding that you are describing. We have actually just introduced a brand new Groom Mate trimmer that we are calling the Platinum XL Professional... If you are interested, we would be more than happy to provide you with one of these new trimmers.\\"<br /><br />I was excited that they were honoring their lifetime guarantee.<br /><br />Not so fast.<br /><br />Two weeks later, I hadn't received anything or heard anything, so I emailed them again. No response.<br /><br />One month later, still nothing, so I emailed again. No response.<br /><br />Nine months later, I just ended up throwing them away, and I posted a negative review on Amazon. The negative review got the attention of the company; they contacted me, apologized for not responding to either of my emails, and promptly sent me one of their new models. I am trying it out now, and will update this review if there aren't any further issues after a few months of use.

I realize it is not going an item to call all your friends about or discuss with excitement over dinner, but when a device works well in this age of exaggerated advertisement, it deserves proper acknowledgement. One key instruction to be highlited (for those who typically skip reading them): Rotate the base back and forth to operate the trimmer, rather than in one constant direction. Other than that - prepare yourself for simplicity, quality, and satisfaction.

This is more costly than other nose & hair trimmers, but this is one that will last, doesn't need batteries and cuts perfectly.<br /><br />I pinch the unit between two fingers and then use my other hand to twist. The entire unit does not twist, only the internal cutting block. So you twist back and forth as you move amongst troubled areas.<br /><br />For cleaning, rinse under water - easy. For more in depth cleaning you can disassemble with one screw to clean & lubricate.<br /><br />This is a perfect travel accessory as its so small and easy to use.<br /><br />Made in the USA and backed by excellent support.After 3 years of use, I had a problem and contacted the manufacture.   985. Getting older and dealing with hair on my body where it didn't used to be has just become a grim reality I've had to accept. Likewise, as I brace myself for the grim reality of the rapidly approaching post-industrial crash of our petroleum based society, where the abundance of electricity i take so much for granted now will be a story i tell to wide-eyed disbelieving youngsters....well, it just seems that every little thing i do to ween myself from the cheaply made and easily disposable goods that define our culture, especially those that run on batteries or plug in --when they don't necessarily have to-- is a token step in the right direction. So it was with much civic pride that I ordered this self-powered nose and ear hair trimmer thingey.....and i'll be damned, it works like a charm. the package says that it's built to last forever, so i look forward to keeping up my grooming habits while fending off hoards of looters in the not so distant future....
  986. If you keep rotating it in the same direction, it grabs the hairs (instead of cutting them) and then yanks them out. Ouch! But it still won't grab/cut the hair.<br /><br />I wanted it as a compact solution for travel, but it's just not going to \\"cut it.\\" I'll have to pack my day-to-day go-to, the [[ASIN:B000W405SG Philips Norelco NT9110 Nose and Ear Hair Trimmer]].
