  1021. I think there are two kinds of people.<br /><br />1) Who think all nose hairs are bad.<br /><br />2) Who believe that nose hairs are good, as long as they're not visible.<br /><br />If you belong in the first category, this is an excellent product. Very well made, good material, sharp edge, safe design and so on. It will trim 95% of your hair down to nothing.<br /><br />However, the 5% of the hairs this thing will not trim, are the worst offenders (in my opinion). The ones that are visible. Those, you'll have to trim using another method. This tool does not lend itself much to focusing on a specific area. A scatter gun more than a shot gun, if you may.<br /><br />I belong to the second category of people. Hence for me, this tool this pretty much useless. I know I may sound like an old fashioned technophobe, but I think the best thing you can use is a good pair of scissors.

  1026. I do a lot of research and reading of reviews before purchasing anything for the first time sight unseen (Internet). Despite the overwhelming amount of positive reviews, I was still concerned over the negative reviews. It took me a couple of months to bite but I am glad that I did finally bite...<br /><br />There is nothing wrong with this product or design.<br /><br />I have been looking for one of these twist type nose hair trimmers for 20 years or so; my father had one similar long ago, as I get older and more of his genetics are unlocked in me, I recognize more now than ever the need for this thing. About ten years ago, I purchased one of the single hand pinch types, I did not use it long as it grabbed and ripped hairs out on a regular basis. This twist type is super sharp, the tolerances are tight and the material and manufacturing are quality.<br /><br />Although, I did not have a problem with twisting slowly, the key to keep from grabbing and yanking out hairs is that you have to twirl it with a little bit of speed. Additionally, this thing is not designed to give you a smooth shave inside your nose or ears, its meant to give you a hair cut; I have used electric units in the past and they are most often designed to get closer to the base of the hair, this trimmer is EXACTLY what it says it is, a trimmer! Therefor, you are going to have a little stubble after a trim.<br /><br />I like stainless steel, I like manufacturing in the United States, I like quality products that lasts, I like this trimmer!
  1027. The Groom Mate is sturdy, the blades are sharp, and it cuts cleanly. The instructions tell you to turn it back and forth, not just turning it in one direction, and I've never had a tugged hair.

  1057. I've used the Groom Mate Platinum XL since 2009, and it has always worked great until recently, when it started to become painful to use. They wrote back within an hour to confirm my address, and they priority shipped me a new one for free. For a product I'd purchased 3 years ago. If that isn't customer service and standing behind your product, I don't know what is. The new trimmer came today and it works just like I remembered!<br /><br />One tip I'd give as a long term user- the packaging says that when you clean out the trimmer (by taking the small screw off the side)- to use household oil to re-lubricate it before putting it back together. Had I done this, I'm guessing my trimmer would have lasted longer.

Takes a very little bit to get used to it but I adjusted in a minute. I highly recommend it!
  1078. Does what the description says it will do, is easy to use, never needs batteries, and is very sturdily constructed.
  1079. Way more effective than the electric models I have been using. Its also better made, you can't really break it without trying really hard.
  1080. I was pretty skeptical about this product. I've used ear and nose trimmers from several companies before, and none of them delivered on their promises. Sharper Image, Norelco, Braun, all came up short.<br /><br />Enter the Groom Mates. They just worked. I learned the hard way how to use them, and still hit the occasional (and painful) snag when I am not focused on what I am doing. But , boy, do these deliver the goods. Don't let the negative reviews fool you. They are either people who are too lazy to use these, had a bad experience with shipping(its not a product problem) or they are paid to put up negative reviews for this product with links to their sponsor's product.<br /><br />I don't use these on my ears, just my nose, and they work fine.
  1081. very handy little tool.

  1091. If, like me, you find yourself growing an ever-increasing amount of annoying nose hair as you get into early adulthood, this nose hair trimmer is fantastic. It's manual so there is basically no maintenance required. It takes a little bit of work to learn how to use it effectively (e.g. holding it at the correct angle, getting hairs into the grooves, etc.), but it's totally worth it. This is the only nose hair trimmer you will ever need.
  1092. These are heavy stainless construction, and work great. It is nice to be able to run it under the faucet to clean it without worry. Let it air dry and throw it back in the drawer.   1099. I'm a bit surprised by the amazing reviews on here. There is plenty to like about the product but it is far from perfect or even ideal.<br /><br />What I like:<br />-Build quality is excellent. There is no doubt it will last a long time.<br />-It's compact and does take up much space making it easy for travel.<br />-No batteries to wear out. Your fingers and the blade do all the work<br />-does a decent job of trimming your nose hair<br /><br />What I dislike:<br />-Anyone who claims it is pain-free is out of their minds. It's not torture like plucking your hair with tweezers but you definitely feel uncomfortable tugs throughout the process. Someone with a sensitive nose like me will definitely prefer something electric.<br />-Because it's so small, it takes some finesse to use. Big fingers like mine can be an issue.<br />-the trimming it provides isn't extremely close. Most nose/ear hair trimmers suffer from this same problem but it seems to me that there has to be a close trim available somewhere.<br />-takes longer than electric. Perhaps I'm just lazy but I prefer electric in this regard.<br /><br />In the end, I have yet to find a nose/ear hair trimmer that I like. This one does the job but I find myself avoiding it because it is mildly painful and obnoxious to use.

  1115. I bought this thing cause I wanted to look more clean and professional. Today I saw one of my supervisors and saw the giant hairs sticking out of his nose.   1116. Great U.S. made product. I've had it for 4 years now and it still works great!
  1117. But, the manufacturer of this one deserves accolades. It is a sturdy, hefty little thing, maneuvers easily (in nose and ears), and cuts closely and thoroughly. I've never found an electric one that works well, and was inconvenienced by how often batteries had to be replaced (only to find the interior corroded, probably because of the moist environment provided by bathrooms). As for other non-electric trimmers, the only other variety I have seen requires a pinching action of the thumb and forefinger (or some finger) to clip. However, that pinching action causes the blades to actually deflect away from the target, or else significant practice to perfect the technique). This one, not at all; one hand holds the nicely knurled barrel of the trimmer near the nose or ear, and the other hand twists the knurled grip at the other end. The action is smooth and (as mentioned) the product is sturdy and hefty (considering its diminutive size), resulting in easy maneuvering and a precise cut. I am glad to have discovered this product, and encourage others to give it a shot.
  1118. This trimmer works great. The electric trimmer I had would loose power then jam, hair would be caught and I could only pull on it. With this manual trimmer when you feel it pulling just twist harder to cut the hair. You can easily create more torque than an electric. Keep the blades moving and it only pulls a little. Just go slow and work it around. I use it while watching TV and don't pull on it if I feel a pinch. I just keep rotating it to cut the hair, then move it with no pinching. Follow the directions and only rotate the end opposite the blades while holding the blade end steady.
  1119. I didn't notice this was non-electric (no batteries) and purchased it for my 91 year old father. He is a little shakey and so holding it and twisting the bottom is not an easy task. I will be purchasing a battery operated one for him. My husband used it ok and it seems to work ok. It's just a little cumbersome.
  1120. Shoving anything sharp up your nose is a pretty scary thing to do, but it does help to know that it's not an electrically powered with a motor that can possibly fling a shrapnel up into the passage. And I read that the other manual kind with spring inside can also break suddenly and slit inside your nose. (ugh...) So glad this one has no springing action anywhere.<br />Surprisingly, it does trim my hair nicely and it's easy to clean. I do have to say that it's unnecessarily heavy and a bit too small for comfort when turning to trim.<br />WARNING: It still can cause a pain if you pull out the trimmer before completely trimming off the hair because hair will get caught wedged between the rotating blade and you will yank out your hair instead.<br />It might be the way it trims the hair though, my nose hair hasn't been growing back in a way to irritate me since I trimmed it last time, which was about 2 months ago. Very convenient tool, I'd say.
